{{Infobox person | name = Katti Anker Møller | image = Portrett av Katti Anker Møller, ca 1910 (cropped).jpg | caption = Katti Anker Møller, c. 1910 | birth_name = Cathrine Anker | birth_date = {{Birth date|1868|10|23|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Hamar]] in [[Hedmark]], Norway | death_date = {{Death date and age|1945|08|20|1868|10|23|df=yes}} |death_place= [[Torsnes]] in [[Østfold]], Norway | occupation = Children's rights advocate, reproductive rights pioneer, lecturer | signature = Katti Anker Møller Signatur 1929 (cropped).jpg | parents = [[Herman Anker]] | children = [[Tove Mohr]] | spouse = [[Kai Møller]] }} [[File:NKNs første styre 1904.jpg|thumb|250 px|First meeting of the National Women's Council (1904). Left to right: [[Karen Grude Koht]], [[Fredrikke Marie Qvam]], [[Gina Krog]], [[Betzy Kjelsberg]] and Katti Anker Møller ]] '''Katti Anker Møller''' (23 October 1868 – 20 August 1945) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] feminist, [[Children's rights movement|children's rights]] advocate, and a pioneer of [[reproductive rights]]. <ref>{{cite web|url = https://snl.no/Katti_Anker_M%C3%B8ller |title= Katti Anker Møller|publisher =Store norske leksikon|author= Elisabeth Lønnå|accessdate= March 1, 2018}}</ref>
==Biography== She was born Cathrine Anker in [[Hamar]], the daughter of [[Herman Anker]]. She had nine siblings and grew up around the first [[folk high school]] at [[Sagatun Folk High School|Sagatun]] in Hamar, which was founded by her father. Educated as a teacher, she spent a year in [[France]], where her exposure to the life of [[prostitutes]] and single mothers affected her profoundly. Her mother died at the age of 50, apparently exhausted from her many pregnancies though the number of children she had was normal for her time. <ref>{{cite web|url = https://nbl.snl.no/Herman_Anker |title= Herman Anker|publisher =Norsk biografisk leksikon|author= Oddvar Vormeland |accessdate= March 1, 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url = http://kvinnesak.no/aeresmedlemmer/katti-anker-moller/ |title= Katti Anker Møller|publisher = Norsk Kvinnesaksforening|accessdate= March 1, 2018}}</ref>
She married her cousin [[Kai Møller]] from Thorsø Manor (''Thorsø herregård'') in [[Torsnes]] in 1889, with whom she had three children. Among themwere the physician [[Tove Mohr]], whose daughter [[Tove Pihl]] has carried on the [[pro-choice]] activism in [[Norway]]. Møller took an early interest in the dangers of too many childbirths, and the plight of unmarried women and their [[Illegitimacy|children]]. Her [[modus operandi]] was to travel and give lectures in local meetings, a revolutionary approach for a woman of her time. <ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.thorsoe.no/History.htm |title= History of Thorsø Herregård|publisher = Thorsø Herregård |accessdate= March 1, 2018}}</ref><ref >{{cite encyclopedia|title=Tove Mohr |first= |last= |encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]] |editor-last=Godal | editor-first=Anne Marit | editor-link=Anne Marit Godal |publisher=Norsk nettleksikon |url=http://snl.no/Tove_Mohr |language=Norwegian |accessdate=March 1, 2018}}</ref>
In collaboration with her brother-in-law [[Johan Castberg]], she worked tirelessly to legislate the rights of children born out of wedlock. This culminated in the institution of the so-called [[Castberg laws]] passed by the [[Stortinget|Norwegian parliament]] in 1915. These laws were revolutionary in their time in giving illegitimate children full rights of inheritance and the right to use their father's surname. <ref>{{cite web|url = https://nbl.snl.no/Johan_Castberg |title= Johan Castber|publisher =Norsk biografisk leksikon |author= Øivind Bjørnson|accessdate= March 1, 2018}}</ref>
She then turned her attention to decriminalizing [[abortion in Norway]], an idea she presented through a lecture called "the liberation of motherhood," with the subtitle "the production of children under culture, the woman's right to decide over her own body." This was met with broad opposition, also from women. She was not dissuaded and continued her efforts, adding [[birth control]] to her causes. In spite of opposition from opinion leaders such as [[Sigrid Undset]], she managed to establish the first "hygiene office" in Oslo to inform women on contraception. <ref>{{cite web|url = https://nbl.snl.no/Katti_Anker_M%C3%B8ller |title= Katti Anker Møller|publisher =Norsk biografisk leksikon|author= Elisabeth Lønnå|accessdate= March 1, 2018}}</ref>
The [[Norwegian National Women's Council]] (''Norske Kvinners Nasjonalråd'') was founded in 1904 as an umbrella organization for various Norwegian women's associations. She served as a member of the organization together with fellow rights activists [[Karen Grude Koht]], [[Fredrikke Marie Qvam]], [[Gina Krog]] and [[Betzy Kjelsberg]].<ref>{{cite web|url = https://snl.no/Norske_Kvinners_Nasjonalr%C3%A5d|title= Norske Kvinners Nasjonalråd|publisher = Store norske leksikon |author= Elisabeth Lønnå|accessdate= February 1, 2018}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==Related reading== * [[Tove Mohr]]: ''Katti Anker Møller: en banebryter''. 1976. Oslo. Tiden Norsk Forlag. {{ISBN|82-10-01258-4}}
==External links== {{Commons}} * [http://www.leksikon.org/art.php?n=1811 Danish article on Møller] * [http://www.nrk.no/programmer/tv_arkiv/kvardagsliv/eit_nytt_kvinneliv/522421.html Biography by Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation] * [http://ostfold.kulturnett.no/kvinner/katti_anker_moller.html Biographical notes related to a statue of Møller]
{{Authority control}}

page.title: Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= KTU |country= [[South Korea]] |affiliation= [[Korean Confederation of Trade Unions|KCTU]] |members= 77,000 |full_name= Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union |native_name= 전국교직원노동조합 |image= |founded= 1989 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Seoul]], South Korea |people= |website= [http://english.eduhope.net/ english.eduhope.net] |footnotes= }}
{{Infobox Korean name| hangul=전국교직원노동조합 (전교조)| hanja=全國敎職員勞動組合 (全敎組)| rr=Jeon-guk Gyojigwon Nodong Johap (Jeon-gyojo)| mr=Chŏn-guk Kyojigwŏn Nodong Chohap (Chŏnkyocho)| }} The '''Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union''' (KTU, {{lang-ko|전국교직원노동조합}}), also known as '''Jeon<small>(-)</small>gyojo''' ({{lang-ko|전교조}}; acronym for ''KTU'' in Korean language) is a [[trade union|labor union]] of teachers in [[South Korea]]. The organization has 77,000 members<ref>[http://koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2009/06/137_46198.html Private Education and Teachers]</ref> (down from 94,000) among the 360,000 public and private school teachers in the country.
The KTU was founded in 1989 under opposition from the South Korean government. In response to its founding, several thousand members were subsequently fired by the education authorities. The KTU finally received official recognition in 1999 after the election of [[Kim Dae-Jung]] and many of the dismissed teachers were allowed to return to their former positions.
A major contributor to the [[Korean Confederation of Trade Unions]], the KTU is criticized for promoting pro-[[Juche|North Korea]] ideology<ref>[http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200607/200607250022.html Teachers' Union Puts Faith in N.Korean History Book]</ref><ref>[http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?biid=2006072699278 Pro-North Teaching Agenda Uncovered]</ref><ref>[http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_editorial/185757.html The revival of freedom of speech violations from years past]</ref><ref>[http://seoul.eduhope.net/bbs/view.php?board=seoul-830&id=193 새학기 환경미화 통일란 참고자료(지부통일위)]</ref> as well as disseminating "[[Anti-American sentiment in Korea|anti-American]]" propaganda.<ref>[http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/10/117_27328.html Teachers Seek to Warn Students of US Beef Risk]</ref><ref>[http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/10/117_27050.html Teacher Beats Student Over US Beef]</ref>
By 2009, the KTU's ranks had dwindled,<ref>[http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/02/113_19811.html Teachers union to shed its radical image]</ref> possibly due to parental and public opposition to its non-education-related political activities. A series of scandals also deeply undermined the union's credibility, including the attempted cover-up of a sexual assault on one of its members, as well as the sexual harassment of trainee teachers by KTU members.<ref>[http://koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2009/05/117_45034.html Teachers' Union has image problem]</ref><ref>[http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2904466 Rotten behavior, rotten union]</ref>
In July 2009, the KTU's offices were raided by police on charges of issuing an anti-government statement allegedly in violation of the Civil Servants Law and the Educational Workers Labor Union Act, which bans political activities for teachers' unions on matters unrelated to working conditions.<ref>[http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?bicode=080000&biid=2009070409738 Teachers' Union Must Be Punished]</ref> Union officials protested the investigation for being politically motivated.<ref>[http://koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2009/07/113_47884.html]</ref><ref>[http://www.koreaherald.co.kr/NEWKHSITE/data/html_dir/2009/07/04/200907040030.asp Police raid teachers' union offices]</ref> Per request by the KTU, the [[Education International]], a multinational federation of teachers' unions, protested the investigations in a formal letter.<ref>[http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_international/364385.html Education International protests S. Korea’s punishment against teachers]</ref>
On April 2010, [[New Right (South Korea)|New Right]] politician [[Cho Jun-hyuk]] revealed the list of teachers who are affiliated with the KTU. This has led to a series of court decisions against him. This has later backfired as the KTU sought to file compensations against him.<ref>{{cite news | title = Teachers union to file compensation suit against ruling party lawmakers | date = 2010-09-08 | url = http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2010/09/08/60/0302000000AEN20100908002000315F.HTML | work = Yonhap News | accessdate = 2011-12-17}}</ref>
On February 2011, the Seoul Metropolitan Education Board approved two KTU-affiliated school principals that caused controversies in their admission process.<ref>{{cite news | first = 준삼 (Jun-sam) | last = 이 (Lee) | script-title=ko:`전교조 교장' 논란 가열…또 양분되는 교육계 | date = 2011-02-15 | url = http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/bulletin/2011/02/15/0200000000AKR20110215155800004.HTML | work = Yonhap News | accessdate = 2011-03-03 | language = Korean}}</ref>
On May 2011, KTU sued Gyeonggi-do regional politician Bak Gwang-jin, for releasing a list of teachers affiliated with the KTU.<ref>{{cite news | first = 철환 (Cheol-hwan) | last = 황 (Hwang) | script-title=ko:전교조 '조합원 명단공개' 前도의원 고소키로 | date = 2011-05-04 | url = http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/bulletin/2011/05/04/0200000000AKR20110504207500004.HTML | work = Yonhap News | accessdate = 2011-05-06 | language = Korean}}</ref>
On May 16, 2011, the head of a conservative parents' interest group ''Gyohakyeon'' (교육과 학교를 위한 학부모 연합) sent letters to approximately 60,000 KTU-affiliated teachers ''to resign their affiliation with KTU''.<ref>{{cite news | first = Hyeon-suk (현숙) | last = Song (송) | script-title=ko:전교조 교사에 "탈퇴하라" 편지 | date = 2011-05-25 | url = http://news.khan.co.kr/kh_news/khan_art_view.html?artid=201105252140415&code=940401 | work = Kyunghyang Sinmun | accessdate = 2011-08-28 | language = Korean}}</ref>
On December 9, 2011, the [[Incheon District Court]] released an official statement that the decision made by the Superintendent of Incheon Metropolitan Office of Education to penalize KTU-affiliated teachers for donating "illegal" funding to the [[Democratic Labor Party (South Korea)|Democratic Labor Party]] is unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite news | first = Sang-hui (상희) | last = Bae (배) | script-title=ko:법원 "정당 후원 교사 징계는 정치적 자유 침해" | date = 2011-12-09 | url = http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/bulletin/2011/12/09/0200000000AKR20111209208200065.HTML | work = Yonhap News | accessdate = 2011-12-10 | language = Korean}}</ref>
==Oppositions== The South Korean [http://studentfirst.co.kr/ Parents' Association for Reviving Public Education] is a well-known opposition group against the KTU.
==See also== {{Portal|Organized labour}} * [[List of Korea-related topics]] * [[Education in South Korea]] * [[Politics of South Korea]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://english.eduhope.net/ KTU] (English) *[http://english.eduhope.net/manifesto.html FOUNDING MANIFESTO OF THE KOREAN TEACHERS AND EDUCATIONAL WORKERS UNION] *[http://english.eduhope.net/chamgyoyook.htm True Education]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Korean Teachers and Education Workers' Union}}
[[Category:Trade unions in South Korea]] [[Category:Education in South Korea]] [[Category:Education trade unions]] [[Category:Teaching in South Korea]]

revision.comment: /* Regulations and Recommendations */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: February of 2010 → February 2010
revision.text:
'''Lack of [[physical education]]''' is the inadequacy of the provision and effectiveness of [[exercise]] and physical activity within modern [[education]].<ref>{{citation |title=The disappearance of physical education |author=Shannon W. Weed |year=2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SaSDHAAACAAJ}}</ref>
When physical education fails to meet its goals of providing students with the knowledge base, life [[habit]]s, and [[mindset]] necessary to be physically [[Physical activity level|active]] throughout their lifetime,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sallis|first=James F|year=2012|title=Physical Education's Role in Public Health: Steps Forward and Backward Over 20 Years and HOPE for the Future|url=|journal=Research Quarterly for Exercise and Sport|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> it can lead children to adopt a [[sedentary lifestyle]]. According to a 2010 study by the [[World Health Organization|WHO]], 81% of children aged 11–17 worldwide did not meet the minimum recommended [[Physical exercise|exercise]] guidelines of 60 minutes daily.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/gho/ncd/risk_factors/physical_activity_text/en/|title=WHO {{!}} Prevalence of insufficient physical activity|website=www.who.int|access-date=2016-11-23}}</ref> [[File:Physical education class.jpg|thumb|A physical education class for secondary students in Havana, Cuba.]] Although more prevalent in countries of [[high income]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hallal|first=Pedro C|last2=Andersen|first2=Lars Bo|last3=Bull|first3=Fiona C|last4=Guthold|first4=Regina|last5=Haskell|first5=William|last6=Ekelund|first6=Ulf|title=Global physical activity levels: surveillance progress, pitfalls, and prospects|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0140673612606461|journal=The Lancet|volume=380|issue=9838|pages=247–257|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(12)60646-1}}</ref> physical inactivity is an [[international]] issue that is correlated with an [[obesity]] epidemic<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://med.stanford.edu/news/all-news/2014/07/lack-of-exercise--not-diet--linked-to-rise-in-obesity--stanford-.html|title=Lack of exercise, not diet, linked to rise in obesity, Stanford research shows|website=News Center|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref> and negative physical,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=I-Min|last2=Shiroma|first2=Eric J|last3=Lobelo|first3=Felipe|last4=Puska|first4=Pekka|last5=Blair|first5=Steven N|last6=Katzmarzyk|first6=Peter T|title=Effect of physical inactivity on major non-communicable diseases worldwide: an analysis of burden of disease and life expectancy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(12)61031-9|journal=The Lancet|volume=380|issue=9838|pages=219–229|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(12)61031-9}}</ref> psychological,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ploughman|first=Michelle|date=2008-01-01|title=Exercise is brain food: The effects of physical activity on cognitive function|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/17518420801997007|journal=Developmental Neurorehabilitation|volume=11|issue=3|pages=236–240|doi=10.1080/17518420801997007|issn=1751-8423|pmid=18781504}}</ref> and [[Academia|academic]] consequences <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rasberry|first=Catherine N.|last2=Lee|first2=Sarah M.|last3=Robin|first3=Leah|last4=Laris|first4=B.A.|last5=Russell|first5=Lisa A.|last6=Coyle|first6=Karin K.|last7=Nihiser|first7=Allison J.|title=The association between school-based physical activity, including physical education, and academic performance: A systematic review of the literature|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0091743511000557|journal=Preventive Medicine|volume=52|pages=S10–S20|doi=10.1016/j.ypmed.2011.01.027}}</ref> in children.
A high quality physical education programs consists of these attributes:<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK201493/|title=Committee on Physical Activity and Physical Education in the School Environment|last=|first=|date=2013|website=National Academy of Sciences|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
* Physical education teachers are certified * Students in elementary school have physical education class for a minimum of 150 minutes per week, while students in high school have it for at least 225 minutes per week * Concrete and achievable standards for students to meet (often for high school graduation)
[[File:Coach Stacey and PE Parachute.jpg|thumb|Elementary students playing with a parachute in their physical education class in Leland, North Carolina, USA.]]
==Causes== The causes of lack of physical education vary from country to country. These include a shortage in facilities and [[Sports equipment|equipment]], a paucity of [[Gym teacher|physical education teachers]], large [[Student–teacher ratio|class sizes]], and budgetary constraints.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> In some African countries such as [[Botswana]] and [[Malawi]], where children attend school for a minimal amount of time, the budgets allocated for physical education are instead used to concentrate on subjects such as [[language]]s and [[mathematics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
A lack of physical education also arises from cultural views: in parts of [[Central America]] (such as the [[The Bahamas|Bahamas]]) and [[Asia]] (such as [[Pakistan]]), exercise is seen as a form of leisure that should not be featured in an academic [[curriculum]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> Another example exists in [[India]], where girls are often discouraged from engaging in [[sport]]s because such activity is viewed as "unfeminine", as is the possibility of them becoming too muscular.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Moreover, a lack of governmental [[legislation]] and intervention can be to blame. In parts of [[South America]] (with the exception of [[Chile]] and [[Colombia]]), there are no laws that make physical education compulsory: thus, it is omitted from many schools.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
In other cases, such as in areas of the [[United States]], the mandated physical education hours are simply not met.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/11/education/even-as-schools-battle-obesity-physical-education-is-sidelined.html|title=Even as Obesity Concerns Rise, Physical Education Is Sidelined|last=Baker|first=Al|date=2012-07-10|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> For example, in 33 states, students are permitted to be exempt from physical education courses by replacing them with other activities such as marching band practices.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/14/2012-shape-of-the-nation-_n_2130115.html|title=Physical Education Programs Stalled By State Loopholes: 2012 Shape Of The Nation Report|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
Outside of school, children often fail to engage in physical activity due to lack of [[physical literacy]], inadequate [[Sleep deprivation|sleep]], the increasing attractiveness of rival pastimes such as [[video game]]s, and parents that do not play their part. It is important that parents allow their children the full opportunity to participate in both formal and informal sports and promote healthy physical activity levels. Also, in achievement-oriented populations such as those seen in [[China]], there is an increased emphasis on [[Test (assessment)|academic results]] which also detracts from physical activity time.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2007/05/30/lack_of_physical_education_weighs_heavily_on_many/ |title=Lack of physical education weighs heavily on many |publisher=The Boston Globe |author=Lisa Wangsness |author2= April Simpson |date=May 30, 2007}}</ref>
The deterioration of physical education in schools combined with the elimination of playgrounds and other play facilities forces children to stay inactive and inside for most of the school day which can have serious long-term consequences.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Weiler|first=Richard|date=2014|title=Is the Lack of Physical Activity Strategy for Children Complicit Mass Child Neglect?|url=|journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine|volume=48|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Consequences == [[File:Medical complications of obesity.png|thumb|Physical consequences of obesity]] An increase in [[sedentary lifestyle]] due to a lack of physical education at home and at school has many physical and psychological consequences on a child in the short and long term.
=== Physical === According to a Portuguese study, children with sedentary lifestyles have nine times poorer [[motor coordination]] than active children of the same age.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lopes|first=Luís|last2=Santos|first2=Rute|last3=Pereira|first3=Beatriz|last4=Lopes|first4=Vítor Pires|date=2012-11-01|title=Associations between sedentary behavior and motor coordination in children|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ajhb.22310/abstract|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|language=en|volume=24|issue=6|pages=746–752|doi=10.1002/ajhb.22310|issn=1520-6300}}</ref> They also have worsened [[bone density]], [[Physical strength|strength]], and [[Flexibility (anatomy)|flexibility]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://healthycanadians.gc.ca/healthy-living-vie-saine/being-active-etre-actif/tips-conseils-eng.php|title=Children and physical activity|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> In the long term, they are more likely to use [[tobacco]], [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]], and [[drug]]s than their active peers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://healthycanadians.gc.ca/healthy-living-vie-saine/being-active-etre-actif/tips-conseils-eng.php|title=Children and physical activity|last=Canada|first=Government of Canada, Health Canada and the Public health Agency of|website=healthycanadians.gc.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Sedentary behaviour is strongly associated with [[obesity]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/82-003-x/2011001/article/11397-eng.htm|title=Physical activity of Canadian children and youth: Accelerometer results from the 2007 to 2009 Canadian Health Measures Survey|website=www.statcan.gc.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> and this imparts a great health risk. Obese children are more likely to have [[Hypertension|high blood pressure]], [[Cardiovascular disease|heart disease]], high [[Low-density lipoprotein|LDL cholesterol]], [[Diabetes mellitus type 2|Type 2 diabetes mellitus]], [[sleep apnea]], [[menstrual cycle]] abnormalities, [[bone]] and [[joint]] problems, increased [[cancer]] risk, and reduced balance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/bariatric/weight-loss-surgery/adolescent-weight-loss/Pages/health-risks.aspx|title=Health Risks of Childhood Obesity - Bariatric and Metabolic Institute {{!}} UC San Diego Health|website=UC Health - UC San Diego|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> They are also more likely to be obese adults.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthyschools/obesity/facts.htm|title=Obesity Prevention {{!}} Healthy Schools {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Childhood physical inactivity has been correlated to cholesterol and fatty streaks in the aorta in the first decade of life and moves to the heart, brain, and other parts of the body in the second and third decade of life, causing health issues.<ref name=":8" />
A lack of physical activity is one of the main causes for obesity, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and other physical health issues among children and adolescents.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Guedes|first=Claudia|date=2007|title=Physical Education and Physical Activity: A Historical Perspective|url=|journal=Journal of Physical Education, Recreation & Dance|volume=78|pages=31-48|via=}}</ref>
There is a direct correlation between active participation in physical activity and the health of school age children, therefore a lack of physical education would cause a lack in physical activity in children, leading to worse health.<ref name=":7" />
=== Psychological === As exercise is known to improve well-being and reduce [[Stress (biology)|stress]], physical inactivity is correlated with poor psychological health<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Goodwin|first=Donna L|year=1996|title=Cut-backs to physical education consulting services: consequences and concerns.|url=|journal=CAHPER Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> such as an increase of major [[Depression (mood)|depression]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Win|first=Sithu|last2=Parakh|first2=Kapil|last3=Eze-Nliam|first3=Chete M.|last4=Gottdiener|first4=John S.|last5=Kop|first5=Willem J.|last6=Ziegelstein|first6=Roy C.|date=2011-03-15|title=Depressive symptoms, physical inactivity and risk of cardiovascular mortality in older adults: the Cardiovascular Health Study|url=http://heart.bmj.com/content/97/6/500|journal=Heart|language=en|volume=97|issue=6|pages=500–505|doi=10.1136/hrt.2010.209767|issn=1468-201X|pmc=3044493|pmid=21339320}}</ref> There is a link between obesity and psychiatric illness and the two feed on each other in a vicious cycle.
A lack of physical activity is associated with poorer [[Concentration (psychology)|concentration]] and [[Academic achievement|academic performance]], particularly in [[mathematics]] and [[Reading (process)|reading]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK201501/|title=Physical Activity, Fitness, and Physical Education: Effects on Academic Performance|last=Harold W. Kohl|first=I. I. I.|last2=Cook|first2=Heather D.|last3=Environment|first3=Committee on Physical Activity and Physical Education in the School|last4=Board|first4=Food and Nutrition|last5=Medicine|first5=Institute of|date=2013-10-30|publisher=National Academies Press (US)|language=en}}</ref>
Obesity induced from lack of exercise also contributes to a decrease in general mental health. Overweight children and teens are more likely to suffer from poor [[self-esteem]], negative [[body image]], [[teasing]], and [[bullying]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthyschools/obesity/facts.htm|title=Obesity Prevention {{!}} Healthy Schools {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Higher levels of sedentary and lower levels of physical education are linked to worse mental health and lower cognitive function among children.<ref name=":8" />
== In Canada ==
=== Current trends === The majority of Canadian children aged 5 to 17 years old (91%) do not meet the daily physical activity recommendations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.participaction.com/en-ca/thought-leadership/report-card/2016|title=Are Canadian Kids Too Tired to Move? {{!}} ParticipACTION|website=ParticipACTION|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> Although Canadian physical education programs are improving significantly, with 61-80% of schools offering a minimum of 150 minutes of physical education classes per week in 2016, and participation levels in [[organized sport]] are on the rise, Canadian school programs are ineffective in encouraging healthy habits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.participaction.com/en-ca/thought-leadership/report-card/2016|title=Are Canadian Kids Too Tired to Move? {{!}} ParticipACTION|website=ParticipACTION|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> In fact, most Canadian children (56%) lack physical literacy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.participaction.com/en-ca/thought-leadership/report-card/2016|title=Are Canadian Kids Too Tired to Move? {{!}} ParticipACTION|website=ParticipACTION|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> Consequently, they face many issues related to lifestyle. These include sedentary behaviours such as increased screen time averaging 176 minutes a day from TVs and video games to the detriment of active play. There is also the inevitable decrease in [[Human-powered transport|active transportation]], more [[sleep deprivation]], and a poor quality of [[Dieting|diet]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.participaction.com/en-ca/thought-leadership/report-card/2016|title=Are Canadian Kids Too Tired to Move? {{!}} ParticipACTION|website=ParticipACTION|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
These lifestyle trends have caused youth obesity rates to nearly triple over the past 30 years. In 2013, this consisted of 28% of Canadian children ages 5–19 that were classified as [[overweight]] or [[Obesity|obese]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://childhoodobesityfoundation.ca/about/|title=About - Childhood Obesity Foundation|newspaper=Childhood Obesity Foundation|access-date=2016-11-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Addressing the Lack of Physical Education ===
==== Recommendations and Regulations ==== The Canadian Association for Health, Physical Education, Recreation and Dance (CAHPERD) has recommended that Canadian schools and [[Board of education|school boards]] take action through specific academic initiatives to ensuring that their physical education [[curriculum]] is effective at encouraging and instilling healthy exercise habits in young Canadians. CAHPERD has suggested that schools focus on checking the quality (adequate facilities, budget and research-verified techniques) and quantity (minimum 30 minutes a day) of a school's physical education courses as well as the professional qualifications of the educators. The consultants should check that classes meet the needs of all students irrespective of [[Race (human categorization)|race]], [[sex]], [[gender]], and [[Agility|ability level]]. The courses should also encourage participation and [[skill]] development, with a healthy balance of [[Competitiveness|competitive]] and noncompetitive activities. Moreover, it is of utmost importance that [[Physical exercise|physical activity]] and [[physical education]] be encouraged by the [[teacher]]: they should never be used to [[Punishment|punish]] a student (such as what is seen through the common practice of making children run if they misbehave). Outside of class hours, CAHPERD recommends that schools provide opportunities for [[Intramural sports|intramural]] activities and involve [[parent]]s in the [[Fitness (biology)|fitness]] initiative.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phecanada.ca/advocacy/advocacy-tools/making-case-physical-education-canada-presentation-kit-leaders|title=Making the Case for Physical Education in Canada: A Presentation Kit for Leaders {{!}} PHE Canada|date=2010-07-23|website=www.phecanada.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
The Pan-Canadian Public Health Network first decided to prioritize the issue of childhood obesity in September 2010 by creating the framework ''Curbing Childhood Obesity: An overview of the Federal, Provincial and Territorial Framework for Action to Promote Healthy Weights.'' In this project, federal, provincial and territorial Ministers of Health agreed to focus on three goals: increasing the predominance of [[Nutrition|nutritious]] food choices, addressing obesity at an early age, and creating better spaces for children that favour physical activity and [[Healthy diet|healthy eating]]. This has allowed the [[action plan]] ''Towards a Healthier Canada'' to be created.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/hp-ps/hl-mvs/framework-cadre/intro-eng.php|title=Curbing Childhood Obesity: An Overview of the FPT Framework for Action to Promote Healthy Weights - Public Health Agency of Canada|last=Canada|first=Government of Canada, Public Health Agency of|website=www.phac-aspc.gc.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
The Canadian Physical Activity guidelines for children ages 5 to 17 consist of at least 1 hour of daily physical activity. Their exercise should range in intensity from [[Moderate exercise|moderate]] (inducing light [[perspiration]] and harder [[breathing]]) to vigorous (inducing heavy perspiration and heavy breathing). Examples of moderate exercise include [[Bicycle|bike]] riding and [[playground]] activities, and examples of vigorous exercise include [[running]] and [[Swimming (sport)|swimming.]] It is recommended that they engage in both vigorous activities and activities strengthening bone and muscles at least three times a week.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csep.ca/en/guidelines/24-hour-movement-guidelines|title=Guidelines|website=www.csep.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
The Canadian Society for Exercise Physiology also recommends that children ages 5 to 17 limit their sedentary activities, such as [[television]] and video games, [[Transport|sedentary transport]], and extensive [[sitting]]. It is advised that children limit their recreational screen time to a maximum of 120 minutes a day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csep.ca/en/guidelines/24-hour-movement-guidelines|title=Guidelines|website=www.csep.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
The ''[[Childhood Obesity]] Foundation'', a Canadian initiative, has invented the 5-2-1-0 [[mnemonic]] to remember the national lifestyle recommendations. This consists of 5 [[Serving size|servings]] or more of [[vegetable]]s and [[fruit]] per day, no more than 2 hours of screen time a day, 1 hour of [[Physical exercise|physical activity]] or more per day, and 0 [[sugary drink]]s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://childhoodobesityfoundation.ca/about/|title=About - Childhood Obesity Foundation|newspaper=Childhood Obesity Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Since the inception of ''Towards a Healthier Canada'', many initiatives have been launched to meet the three goals, and they vary from [[Provinces and territories of Canada|province]] to province.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phn-rsp.ca/thcpr-vcpsre-2015/index-eng.php|title=Towards a Healthier Canada : Compilation of Initiatives|last=|first=|date=|website=towardsahealthiercanada.ca|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> They are projects made in the name of a framework or jurisdictional approach/governmental department that are either targeted at schools, at a community, or in partnership with other organizations or companies.
== In the United States ==
=== Current Trends === Nearly 10 million [[Child|children]] and [[Adolescence|adolescents]] in the United States ages 6–19 are considered [[overweight]] because the lack of physical education in schools. <ref>{{citation|title=Physical Education in Schools|url=http://www.americanheart.org/presenter.jhtml?identifier=3010854}}</ref> Children aged 6–11 have also more than doubled in rate of [[obesity]] over the last twenty years. <ref>{{citation|author=Leslie Haub|title=Childhood obesity and the lack of physical education programs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eGNXNAAACAAJ|year=2007}}</ref>
Individual states have set requirements for physical education in their schools, but how physical education is conducted across the country has not been established. Yet, physical education has been a common practice of the K-12 education curriculum in the United States.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=McKenzie|first=Thomas|date=2017|title=Studies of Physical Education in the United States Using SOFIT: A Review|url=|journal=Research Quarterly for Exercise and Sport|volume=88|pages=492-502|via=}}</ref>
The No Child Left Behind Act has created an environment in which physical education, art and music have been left behind, viewed as "nonessential" courses. Federal funding is more dependent on schools enhancing their math and reading programs.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Sallis|first=James|date=2012|title=Physical Education's Role in Public Health|url=|journal=Research Quarterly for Exercise and Sport|volume=83|pages=125-135|via=}}</ref>
=== Addressing the Lack of Physical Education ===
===== Regulations and Recommendations ===== One program the United States has adopted to decrease obesity are before-school exercise programs with elementary aged children. One in particular consists of reaching 100 miles before the end of the school year. Each milestone of 25 miles the child will earn a check mark on a tee-shirt. They will then be rewarded at 100 miles with a trophy and an announcement over the school loudspeaker. Walking is supervised by teachers and done around school grounds or inside the school. This is a great way for a child to improve health, concentration, confidence and happiness.
Throughout the past two decades, federal support for physical education in the public health sector has increased dramatically. Since 1992, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has funded state education agencies to get them to partner with state health departments to promote physical activity and healthy eating in schools among young people. <ref name=":1" />
In February 2010, first lady Michelle Obama started the "Let's Move" initiative to address the childhood obesity epidemic. Efforts to engage in schools to fight against childhood obesity were taken within 1 year of establishing the program.<ref name=":1" />
Budget cuts in the United States have led to less funding and support for physical education because it is not a "core" subject.<ref name=":1" />
== In China ==
=== Current Trends === Even though obesity has increased among most of the population in China, the burden of obesity has shifted onto the lower educated population, likely due to a lack of physical education or health education.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wang|first=Huijun|date=2013|title=Program and Policy Options for Preventing Obesity in China|url=|journal=National Center for Biotechnology Information|volume=14|pages=134-140|via=}}</ref>
Students in China are beginning to gain equal opportunities to physical education and sports to further improve their physical health and strength.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Tsai|first=Chiung-Tzu Lucetta|date=2017|title=The History of Sports and Physical Education in China|url=|journal=World Leisure Journal|volume=59|pages=326-337|via=}}</ref>
Sport and physical education in China is extremely influenced by Confucianism which emphasizes collectivism. The values it holds emphasizes self-sacrifice and subordination of one's interests to those of others.<ref name=":2" />
=== Addressing the Lack of Physical Education ===
===== Regulations and Recommendations ===== In 2011, The Chinese Ministry of Education has developed standards for physical education in schools. These emphasize enhancing children's health development is the primary goal of physical education in schools.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Ding|first=Haiyong|date=2014|title=A Review of Scholarly and Research Work in Physical Education in China During the First Decade of the 21st Century|url=|journal=Quest|volume=66|pages=117-133|via=}}</ref> These standards include:
* "Standard 1: Physical activity participation—Students participate in physical activities and are able to enjoy exercise and experience success."<ref name=":3" />
* "Standard 2: Mastery of knowledge, skill, and safe exercise methods—Students learn knowledge about exercise, perform physical skills, understand safe exercise principles, and learn self-defense."<ref name=":3" />
* "Standard 3: Developing physical health—Students learn and master knowledge and method of maintaining health, develop and sustain healthy posture and bodily shape, develop and maintain physical fitness, and improve adaptive ability in natural environments."<ref name=":3" />
* "Standard 4: Developing mental health—Students learn to develop mental strength, control emotions, develop ability to collaborate and cooperate, and follow ethical norms of physical activity."<ref name=":3" />
The General Administration of Sport in China has been one of the leading government agencies that promotes the development of physical education and physical health in the elementary and college levels.<ref name=":2" />
The government has for the most part supported physical education and sport in school, but has often abused it as a political tool which leads to ignoring its importance and the needs of individual students.<ref name=":2" />
== In European (EU) Countries ==
=== Current Trends === In the EU, physical education is a mandatory subject in general education. The time dedicated to physical education varies greatly from country to country.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=November 2016|title=Physical Education in EU Schools|url=|journal=Briefing European Parliamentary Research Service|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> About half of EU countries devote 10% of their school curriculum to physical education. Hungary, Croatia and Slovenia devote 15%, while Ireland only 4%.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Matejek|first=Črtomir|date=2014|title=Physical Education in Primary Education in EU Countries|url=|journal=Revija za Elementarno Izobraževanje|volume=7|pages=57-165|via=}}</ref>
Out of all EU countries, France devotes the most time to physical education in elementary school, a total of 108 hours, which is only 10% of the total teaching time.<ref name=":5" />
The primary education designers in European countries view physical education as less important than other subjects.<ref name=":5" />
Physical inactivity is responsible for over 500,000 deaths per year in the European Union and accounts for economic costs of over €80 billion per year.<ref name=":4" />
Funding for physical education in EU schools is poor, which has led to poor quality physical education. This lack of funding is reflected in poor quality and lack of equipment at EU schools in respectively 26% and 38% of EU countries.<ref name=":4" />
=== Addressing the Lack of Physical Education ===
===== Regulations and Recommendations ===== In 2007, the European Parliament's Resolution on the Role of Sport in Education helped parliament conclude that physical education is “the only school subject which seeks to prepare children for a healthy lifestyle and focuses on their overall physical and mental development, as well as imparting important social values such as fairness, self-discipline, solidarity, team spirit, tolerance and fair play…” and one of the most important tools for social integration.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Hardman|first=Ken|date=2008|title=Physical Education in Schools: A Global Perspective|url=|journal=University of Worcester, UK|volume=1|pages=5-28|via=}}</ref>
European Parliament's Resolution places physical education on the European political agenda, highlighting its importance.<ref name=":6" />
The European Physical Education Association recommends daily physical education in elementary grades up to 11 or 12 years of age and 3 hours per week in post-elementary and high school grades.<ref name=":6" />
== See also == * [[Physical education]] *[[Exercise]] *[[Exercise trends]] * [[Sedentary lifestyle]] * [[Fitness professional]] * [[Sport psychology]] * [[Gym]] * [[ParticipACTION]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.phn-rsp.ca/thcpr-vcpsre-2015/videos/healthyweights-poidssante-2015-eng.m4v Promoting Physical Activity and Healthy Living (video)] by the [http://www.phn-rsp.ca/index-eng.php Pan-Canadian Public Health Network] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rasZGZpQsy0 Educating the Student Body: Taking Physical Activity and Physical Education to School (video)] by [http://www.nationalacademies.org/hmd/ The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine: Health and Medicine Division] * [https://www.participaction.com/ ParticipACTION]

revision.text:
{{Other uses|Listening (disambiguation)}} {{essay|date=June 2017}} [[File:Shimer College Susan Henking listening 2013 cropped.jpg|thumb|Listening in conversation.]] '''Listening''' is giving one's attention to sound, for example [[speech]], [[music]] or natural sounds. Listening involves complex affective, cognitive, and behavioral processes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Halone|first1=Kelby|last2=Cunconan|first2=Terry|last3=Coakley|first3=Carolyn|last4=Wolvin|first4=Andrew|title=Toward the establishment of general dimensions underlying the listening process.|journal=International Journal of Listening|date=1998|volume=12|pages=12–28|doi=10.1080/10904018.1998.10499016|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10904018.1998.10499016?journalCode=hijl20}}</ref> Effective processes include the motivation to attend to others; cognitive processes include attending to, understanding, receiving, and interpreting content and relational messages; and behavioral processes include responding with verbal and nonverbal feedback.
==What is listening?== Listening differs from [[Obedience (human behavior)|obeying]]. A person who receives and understands information or an instruction, and then chooses not to comply with it or to agree to it, has listened to the speaker, even though the result is not what the speaker wanted.<ref>Purdy, Michael and Deborah Borisoff, eds. (1997) ''Listening in Everyday Life: A Personal and Professional Approach. ''University Press of America. {{ISBN|9780761804611}}. p. 5–6.</ref> Listening is a term in which the listener listens to the one who produced the sound to be listened.
==Barthes== Semiotician [[Roland Barthes]] characterized the distinction between listening and hearing as "Hearing is a physiological phenomenon; listening is a psychological act." <ref>{{cite book|last=Barthes|first=Roland|title=The Responsibility of Forms|year=1985|publisher=New York Hill and Wang|authorlink=}}</ref> Hearing is always occurring, most of the time subconsciously. In contrast, listening is the interpretative action taken by the listener in order to understand and potentially make meaning out of the sound waves. Listening can be understood on three levels: alerting, deciphering, and an understanding of how the sound is produced and how the sound affects the listener.<ref>{{cite book|last=Barthes|first=Roland|title=In the Responsibility of Forms|year=1985|publisher=New York Hill and Wang|authorlink=}}</ref>
Alerting, the first level, is the detection of environmental sound cues. While discussing this level, Barthes mentions the idea of territory being demarcated by sounds. This is best explained using the example of one's home. One's home, for instance, has certain sounds associated with it that make it familiar and comfortable. An intrusion sound (e.g. a squeaking door or floorboard, a breaking window) alerts the dweller of the home to the potential danger.
Deciphering, the second level, describes detecting patterns in and interpreting sounds. An example of this level is that of a child waiting for the sound of his mother's return home. In this scenario the child is waiting to pick up on sound cues (e.g. jingling keys, the turn of the doorknob, etc.) that will mark his mother's approach.
Understanding, the third level of listening, means knowing how what one says will affect another. This sort of listening is important in [[psychoanalysis]]. Barthes states that the psychoanalyst must turn off their judgement while listening to the analysand in order to communicate with their patient's unconscious in an unbiased fashion.
However, in contrast to the distinct levels of listening listed above, it must be understood that they all function within the same plane, and sometimes all at once. Specifically the second and third levels, which overlap vastly, can be intertwined in that obtaining, understanding and deriving meaning are part of the same process. In that the child, upon hearing the doorknob turn (obtaining), can almost automatically assume that someone is at the door (deriving meaning).
==In language learning== Along with [[speaking]], [[Reading (process)|reading]], and [[writing]], listening is one of the "four skills" of [[language learning]]. All [[language teaching]] approaches except for [[grammar-translation]] incorporate a listening component.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Second Language Listening: Theory and Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0521786479|isbn=0521786479|first1=John |last1=Flowerdew|first2=Lindsay|last2=Miller|year=2005|page=4|ref=harv}}</ref> Some teaching methods, such as [[Total Physical Response]], involve students simply listening and responding.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Teaching Language Arts to English Language Learners|page=171 |url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0415641446 |first1=Anete|last1=Vásquez|first2=Angela L. |last2=Hansen|first3=Philip C. |last3=Smith |year=2013|isbn=0415641446|ref=harv}}</ref>
A distinction is often made between "intensive listening", in which learners attempt to listen with maximum accuracy to a relatively brief sequence of speech, and "extensive listening", in which learners listen to lengthy passages for general comprehension. While intensive listening may be more effective in terms of developing specific aspects of listening ability, extensive listening is more effective in building [[fluency]] and maintaining learner [[motivation]].{{sfn|Flowerdew|2005|p=14}}
==See also== * [[Hearing]] * [[Active listening]] * [[Appreciative listening]] * [[Auditory agnosia]] * [[Auditory processing disorder]] * [[Auditory verbal agnosia]] * [[Dialogic listening]] * [[Informational listening]] * [[Pseudolistening]] * [[Workplace listening]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Zenger, Jack and Folkman, Joseph. [https://hbr.org/2016/07/what-great-listeners-actually-do What Great Listeners Actually Do] (14 July 2016), ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'' *Mailman, Joshua B. "ors for (Music) Listening: DRAMaTIC" in ''Journal of Sonic Studies'' v.2. *Lipari, Lisbeth. Listening, Thinking, Being: Toward an Ethics of Attunement. Penn State University Press. [http://www.psupress.org/books/titles/978-0-271-06332-4.html] * {{fr icon}} Fitzpatrick, Élizabeth M. ''Apprendre à écouter et à parler''. [[University of Ottawa Press|University of Ottawa press 201]] 3. [https://web.archive.org/web/20140424100603/http://130.102.44.245/books/9782760320437?auth=0 Available at]

| teaching_staff = 21<ref name=Rani>http://web01.grameen.com/gc/vcip/database/education.html#rani Rani Bhabani High School at a glance</ref> | school code = 4800<ref name=Madhupur>http://www.dhakaeducationboard.gov.bd/wp-content/themes/bisedhaka/resultstatus.php?scode=4800{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Madhupur Rani Bhabani High School</ref> | gender = Boys & Girls | age range = | medium = Bengali | campus size = 3.93 Acres <ref name=Rani/> | campus type = Non Government <ref name=Rani/> ' | accreditation = | mascot = | sports = [[Association football|Football]], [[cricket]], [[volleyball]] | team_name = | opened = | established = 02-01-39<ref name=Rani/> | students = 1310<ref name=Rani/> | alumni = | enrollment = | communities = | free_label = [[Board of education|Board]] | free_text = [[Dhaka Education Board]] | url = }} [[File:Madhupur Rani Bhabani Pilot Model High School.jpg|thumb|3D view of Madhupur Rani Bhabani Model High School]] '''Madhupur Rani Bhabani High School'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://banbeis.gov.bd/dhaka_gis/pdf/MADHUPUR.pdf |title=Madhupur |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205132148/http://banbeis.gov.bd/dhaka_gis/pdf/MADHUPUR.pdf |archivedate=2015-02-05 |df= }}</ref> ({{Lang-bn|মধুপুর রাণী ভবানী উচ্চ বিদ্যালয়<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dctangail.gov.bd/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=48 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904064934/http://www.dctangail.gov.bd/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=48 |archivedate=2010-09-04 |df= }} শিক্ষা প্রতিষ্ঠানের তালিকা</ref>}}) also known as '''Madhupur Rani Bhabani Pilot High School'''<ref name=Teachers/> is a high school located in [[Madhupur Upazila]], [[Tangail]], [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]]. The school offers education for students ranging from six to [[Secondary School Certificate]] (approximately ages 7 to 15).The school is under the direct control of the [[Ministry of Education (Bangladesh)|Ministry of Education]]
==Location== Madhupur Rani Bhabani High School is one Km from Madhupur bus stand, 45 km from Tangail, Mymensingh and Jamalpur district headquarters and 135 km from Dhaka city.The school is situated by the side of Tangail-Mymensingh highway.<ref name=Rani/>
==Academic performance== Madhupur Rani Bhabani High School's results from 2007 to 2010 for the Secondary School Certificate level examinations are as follows:<ref name=Madhupur/> <center> {| class="wikitable" border="2" |- ! Year ! Number of Examinees ! Number of Passed Students ! Pass Percentage |- | 2007 | 93 | 89 | 95.70% |- | 2008 | 119 | 119 | 100.00% |- | 2009 | 146 | 142 | 97.26% |- | 2010 | 200 | 198 | 99% |- |} </center>
==See also== *[[Alokdia High School]] *[[Madhupur Shahid Smrity Higher Secondary School]] *[[Madhupur College]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Marianne Williams née Coldham |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1793|12|12|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Norwich]], [[England]] |death_date = {{Death date|1879|12|16|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Pakaraka]], [[Bay of Islands]], [[New Zealand]] |other_names = ''Mata Wiremu'' (Mother Williams) |spouse = The Revd. [[Henry Williams (missionary)|Henry Williams]] |known_for = |occupation = Missionary and pioneering educator |nationality = British }}
'''Marianne Williams''', together with her sister-in-law [[Jane Williams (missionary)|Jane Williams]], was a pioneering educator in [[New Zealand]]. They established schools for Māori children and adults as well as educating the children of the [[New Zealand Church Missionary Society|Church Missionary Society]] (CMS) in the [[Bay of Islands]], [[New Zealand]].<ref name="Fitzgerald2004">{{cite book | author=Caroline Fitzgerald | title= Marianne Williams: Letters from the Bay of Islands | year= 2004 | publisher= Penguin Books, New Zealand |location= |language= |isbn=0-14-301929-5 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= }}</ref> The Māori women called her ''Mata Wiremu'' (Mother Williams).<ref name="LMR1874">{{cite book |last1= Rogers |first1= Lawrence M. |authorlink1= |title= Te Wiremu: A Biography of Henry Williams|url= |format= |accessdate= |year=1973 |publisher=Pegasus Press |location= |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page=128 |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= }}</ref>
==Early life== Marianne Williams, née Marianne Coldham, was born in Yorkshire, England 12 December 1793. Marianne was the oldest child of Wright and Anne Coldham. Wright Coldham and Thomas Williams (Marianne’s father-in-law) were hosiers in [[Nottingham]], and both were Sheriffs.<ref name="NHW2"/> The family had moved to [[Nottingham]] from [[Norwich]]. Her father, Wright Coldham, was an active member of the Presbyterian [[High Pavement Chapel]] in Nottingham.<ref name="NHW3">{{cite web| last = Harvey-Williams | first = Nevil | title = The Williams Family in the 18th and 19th Centuries - Part 3|chapter=|date=March 2011|publisher= | url= http://www.williams.gen.nz/18and19c.html| accessdate=21 December 2013}}</ref> Wright Coldham received recognition as a [[Burgess (title)|Burgess]] of Nottingham in 1796;<ref name="NHW2">{{cite web| last = Harvey-Williams | first = Nevil | title = The Williams Family in the 18th and 19th Centuries - Part 2|chapter=|date=March 2011|publisher= | url= http://www.williams.gen.nz/18and19a.html#thogos| accessdate=21 December 2013}}</ref> as a [[Sheriff of Nottingham (position)|Sheriff of Nottingham]] in 1798;<ref name="NHW2"/> and as the Mayor of Nottingham in 1809.<ref name="NHW2"/> In 1810 Anne Coldham died and at the age 16 Marianne took over raising her three sisters, Sarah, Maria and Anne, her blind grandmother Mrs Temple, the running of the mayoral household and acting as Lady Mayoress at civic events. In 1815 Wright Coldham died.<ref name="Caroline Fitzgerald 2004 p. 3">''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' p. 3 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2004)</ref>
Marianne and [[Henry Williams (missionary)|Henry Williams]] were married on 20 January 1818 by Henry’s cousin and brother-in law, the Rev. [[Edward Garrard Marsh|Edward Marsh]], a member of the [[Church Missionary Society]].<ref name="Caroline Fitzgerald 2004 p. 3"/>
Marianne and Henry shared a Christian faith and they joined the [[Church Missionary Society]] (CMS), with the decision eventually being made that Henry would become an ordained minister and CMS missionary in the [[Bay of Islands]], [[New Zealand]]. In a letter to the Committee of the CMS of 6 August 1822, Henry said of Marianne: "''she does not accompany me merely as my wife, but as a fellow-helper in the work''".<ref name="CARv1">{{cite book |last1= Carleton |first1=Hugh |authorlink1= |title= The Life of Henry Williams|url= |format= |accessdate= |year= 1874 |publisher= [[Early New Zealand Books]] (ENZB), University of Auckland Library|location= |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages= |chapter= Vol. I |chapterurl=http://www.enzb.auckland.ac.nz/document?wid=1038&action=null|quote= |ref= |bibcode= }}</ref><ref name="teara.govt.nz">[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/biographies/1w24/1 Sarah Marianne Williams. 'Williams, Marianne - Biography', from the Dictionary of New Zealand Biography. Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand] in ''[[Dictionary of New Zealand Biography]]'' (DNZB)</ref>
==The early years in the Bay of Islands== [[File:HenryWilliamsPaihia.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Watercolour painting by Henry Williams of the CMS mission house at Paihia]] On 11 September 1822 Henry and Marianne and three children embarked on the ''Lord Sidmouth'', a ship carrying women convicts to [[Port Jackson]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australian]].<ref name="RE">{{cite web| last =Robert Espie (Surgeon) | first = | title = Surgeon's Journal of Her Majesty's Female Convict Ship Lord Sidmouth (22 August 1822-1 March 1823) |chapter=|year= |publisher= (Adm. 101/44/10 | url= http://www.femaleconvicts.org.au/docs/ships/LordSidmouth1823_SJ.pdf| accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref>
After a short stay with Rev. [[Samuel Marsden]], he accompanied them on ship the ''Brampton'' from [[Sydney]] to the [[Bay of Islands]], [[New Zealand]] where they arrived at [[Kerikeri]] on 7 August 1823.<ref>''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' (7 August 1823) p. 54 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2004)</ref>
The CMS had an established mission at [[Kerikeri]] where they stayed while Henry and other CMS members and built a store of plank and timber and a [[Typha orientalis|raupo]] hut on [[Paihia]] beach. On 15 September 1823 the family moved into the raupo hut, which Marianne described as having the appearance of a beehive. In 1830 a more substantial house was built using lath and plaster.<ref>''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' (3 September 1830) p. 192, (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2004)</ref>
Chickens, ducks, goats and a horse were brought from [[Sydney]]. A garden was soon cultivated. Food was either cultivated or imported on the infrequent ships from [[Sydney]]. Pork and [[Kumera]] could be traded from the Māori, however in the early days [[musket]]s were the item of barter which Māori wanted to trade, but [[Henry Williams (missionary)|Henry Williams]] refused to trade muskets. The supply of pork and other food was withheld in an attempt to pressure Henry to trade muskets for food.<ref>Rogers, Lawrence M., (1973) ''Te Wiremu: A Biography of Henry Williams'', Pegasus Press pp. 60 & 75-76</ref><ref>''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' (11 February 1824) p. 82 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2004)</ref>
==The protection of the mission by the chiefs of the Ngāpuhi== The members of the mission were under the protection of [[Hongi Hika]], the [[rangatira]] (chief) and war leader of the [[Ngāpuhi]] [[iwi]] (tribe). The immediate protector of the [[Paihia]] mission was the chief Te Koki and his wife [[Ana Hamu]], a woman of high rank and the owner of the land occupied by the mission at [[Paihia]].<ref name="Fitzgerald2004-62">{{cite book |last1= Fitzgerald |first1= Caroline |authorlink1= |title= Marianne Williams: Letters from the Bay of Islands |url= |format= |accessdate= |year=2004|publisher= Penguin Books, New Zealand |location= |language= |isbn=0-14-301929-5 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page=62 |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= }}</ref><ref name="LMR1874tk">{{cite book |last1= Rogers |first1= Lawrence M. |authorlink1= |title= Te Wiremu: A Biography of Henry Williams|url= |format= |accessdate= |year=1973 |publisher=Pegasus Press |location= |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page=55 |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= }}</ref><ref name="Fitzgerald2011">{{cite book |last1= Fitzgerald |first1= Caroline |authorlink1= |title= Te Wiremu: Henry Williams – Early Years in the North |url= |format= |accessdate= |year=2011|publisher= Huia Publishers, New Zealand |location= |language= |isbn=978-1-86969-439-5 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages=25, 39–40 |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= }}</ref>
In 1827 Hongi Hika lead the Ngāpuhi against the tribes at [[Whangaroa]] which caused anxiety amongst the missionaries as they feared they would be caught up in the fighting.<ref>''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' (14 Dec 1826) p. 121, (11-19 Jan 1827) p. 123-131 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2004)</ref> The fears of the missionaries were increased when some of the warriors of Hongi Hika, acting contrary to his orders, plundered and burnt the [[Wesleyanism|Wesleyan]] mission at Whangaroa.<ref>Journal of [[William Williams (bishop)|William Williams]], (1 March 1827) p.89 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2011)</ref> During a skirmish Hongi Hika was shot in the chest by one of his warriors, which resulted in the missionaries fearing that they would suffer in the event that a muru occurred following his death (an attack launched out of respect for a deceased chief).<ref>Journal of [[William Williams (bishop)|William Williams]], (1 March 1827) p. 89 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2011)</ref> On 6 March 1828 [[Hongi Hika]] spent his last moments "exhorting his followers to be valiant, and repel any force, however great, which might come against them - telling them this was all the utu, or satisfaction, that he desired".<ref>Journal of James Stack, Wesleyan missionary (and later CMS missionary), (12 March 1828) p. 99 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2011)</ref>
The death of Tiki, a son of [[Pōmare I (Ngāpuhi)|Pōmare I]] (also called Whetoi)<ref name="Pom1">{{cite web|first= Angela |last= Ballara |title = Pomare I | date =30 October 2012|url= http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/biographies/1p19/pomare-i |publisher= Dictionary of New Zealand Biography. Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=4 March 2014}}</ref> and the subsequent death of [[Te Whareumu]] in 1828 threw the [[Hokianga]] into a state of uncertainty as the other Ngāpuhi chiefs debated what revenge was required. Henry was asked to mediate between the combatants.<ref name="Fitzgerald101">{{cite book |last1= Fitzgerald |first1= Caroline |authorlink1= |title= Marianne Williams: Letters from the Bay of Islands |url= |format= |accessdate= |year=2004|publisher= Penguin Books, New Zealand |location= |language= |isbn=0-14-301929-5 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page=101 |pages=|chapter= Journal of Marianne Williams, (17 March 1828) |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= }}</ref> As the Ngāpuhi chiefs did not want to escalate the fighting, a peaceful resolution was achieved.<ref name="Fitzgerald107">{{cite book |last1= Fitzgerald |first1= Caroline |authorlink1= |title= Te Wiremu: Henry Williams – Early Years in the North |url= |format= |accessdate= |year=2011|publisher= Huia Publishers, New Zealand |location= |language= |isbn=978-1-86969-439-5 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages=101–107 |chapter= Journals of Henry Williams, Marianne Williams & William Williams, (16–28 March 1828) |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= }}</ref>
In 1830 there was a battle, at [[Kororareka]] (Russell), that is called the [[Girls' War]],<ref>[http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-SmiMaor-t1-body-d73.html online] at [[New Zealand Electronic Text Centre|NZETC]]</ref><ref name=smith>Smith, S. Percy – Maori Wars of the Nineteenth Century. Christchurch 1910</ref> which also caused the missionaries to fear they would be caught up in the fighting.<ref>''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' (12–17 March 1829) p. 139-41 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2004)</ref>
While there were misunderstandings and arguments between the missionaries and the Ngāpuhi, the CMS mission was never threatened.
==The Paihia mission== {{See also|New Zealand Church Missionary Society}} The missionary work of [[Henry Williams (missionary)|Henry Williams]] and his attempts to act as peacemaker in intertribal conflicts meant that he spent months at a time travelling through the North Island of New Zealand. Marianne shared mission responsibilities with her sister-in-law, Jane Williams, together they cared for and educated their families. Together with [[Jane Williams (missionary)|Jane Williams]], Marianne set up a boarding school for Māori girls;<ref>''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' (16 October 1826) p. 112 (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2004)</ref> and provided classes to the children of CMS missionaries in the morning with schools for Māori children and adults in the afternoon.<ref>''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' (6 Nov 1826) pp. 116 & 133 (Caroline Fitzgerald 2004)</ref> Schools were established in the communities inland from the [[Bay of Islands]]. Marianne trained and supervised the teachers, who were her daughters, nieces or future daughters-in-law.<ref name="teara.govt.nz"/>
The domestic responsibilities of Marianne extended beyond her large family and included Māori and [[Pakeha]] visitors to the mission as well as providing assistance to other CMS members in [[Paihia]], [[Kerikeri]] and [[Waimate North]].<ref>Rogers, Lawrence M., (1973) ''Te Wiremu: A Biography of Henry Williams'', Pegasus Press</ref><ref>''Letters from the Bay of Islands'' (Caroline Fitzgerald, 2004)</ref> Marianne and Henry had eleven children:<ref name=faith19>Evans 1992, p. 19</ref> [[File:Henry and Marianne Williams gravestones.jpg|thumb|right|400px|alt=Gravestones of Henry and Marianne Williams, Holy Trinity Church, Pakaraka|Gravestones of Henry and Marianne Williams, Holy Trinity Church, Pakaraka]] * [[Edward Marsh Williams|Edward Marsh]] (2 November 1818 – 11 October 1909).<ref>{{cite web| last = | first = | title = Williams, Edward Marsh 1818–1909|chapter=|year =1952|publisher=[[Early New Zealand Books]] (NZETC) | url= http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-PlaNine-t1-body-d1-d1287.html | accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> Married Jane Davis, daughter of CMS missionary the Revd Richard Davis. * Marianne (28 April 1820 – 25 November 1919). Married CMS missionary the Revd Christopher Pearson Davies.<ref name="HER">{{cite web |first = | last = |title=Widow of the Missionary |work= New Zealand Herald, Volume LVI, Issue 17332, 2 December 1919, Page 8|accessdate=18 October 2015 |url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NZH19191202.2.89| publisher =National Library of NZ}}</ref> * [[Samuel Williams (missionary)|Samuel]] (17 January 1822 – 14 March 1907).<ref name="SamW">{{cite web|first=Mary |last= Boyd |title = Williams, Samuel - Biography | date =1 Sep 2010|url= http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/biographies/1w25/1|publisher= Dictionary of New Zealand Biography. Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=17 March 2012}}</ref> Married Mary Williams, daughter of William and Jane Williams. * [[Henry Williams (New Zealand politician)|Henry]] (10 November 1823 – 6 December 1907).<ref name="NZETC Henry Williams">{{cite book |title=The Cyclopedia of New Zealand : Auckland Provincial District |year=1902 |url= http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz/tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc02Cycl-t1-body1-d2-d22-d2.html#name-101696-mention |publisher=[[The Cyclopedia of New Zealand]] |author=Cyclopedia Company Limited |accessdate=1 October 2012 |location=Christchurch |chapter= The Hon. Henry Williams}}</ref> Married Jane Elizabeth Williams (also a daughter of William and Jane). * Thomas Coldham Williams (18 July 1825 – 19 May 1912). Married Annie Palmer Beetham, daughter of [[William Beetham]]. * [[John William Williams|John William]] (6 April 1827 – 27 April 1904). Married Sarah Busby, daughter of [[James Busby]]. * Sarah (26 February 1829 – 5 April 1866). Married Thomas Bidulph Hutton. * Catherine (Kate) (24 February 1831 – 8 January 1902). Married the Revd [[Octavius Hadfield]]. * Caroline Elizabeth (13 November 1832 – 20 January 1916). Married Samuel Blomfield Ludbrook. * Lydia Jane (2 December 1834 – 28 November 1891). Married [[Hugh Carleton]]. * Joseph Marsden (5 March 1837 – 30 March 1892).
==Life at Pakaraka== Henry and Marianne moved to [[Pakaraka]] when Henry refused to back down in an argument with Governor [[George Grey]] over the amount of land Henry had acquired so as to provide for his children. In this argument Bishop Selwyn took the side of Grey, and in 1849 the CMS decided to dismiss Henry from service. However, in 1854 Henry was reinstated to the CMS following representations to the CMS by Governor Grey, Bishop Selwyn and supporters of Henry Williams.<ref name=mitcalfe35>Mitcalfe 1963, p. 35</ref>
Henry and Marianne lived in the house known as ''The Retreat'', that still stands at Pakaraka.<ref>see: [http://williamshistorichouse.org.nz/ the website] of the Henry and William Williams Memorial Museum Trust</ref>
Marianne Williams died at [[Pakaraka]], [[New Zealand]], on 16 December 1879 and was buried in the grounds of the Holy Trinity Church at [[Pakaraka]] alongside the grave of [[Henry Williams (missionary)|Henry Williams]].
==Literature and sources== * {{Cite book | last = Rogers | first = Lawrence M. (editor) | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = ''The Early Journals of Henry Williams 1826 to 1840''
| publisher = Pegasus Press | year = 1961 | location = | pages = | url = http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-RogEarl.html | doi = | id = | isbn = }} * Carleton, Hugh (1874) ''The life of Henry Williams, Archdeacon of Waimate''. Auckland NZ. [http://www.enzb.auckland.ac.nz/document/1874_-_Carleton,_H._The_Life_of_Henry_Williams,_%5BVol._I._%5D Online available] from [[Early New Zealand Books]] (ENZB). * Evans, Rex D. (compiler) (1992) ''Faith and farming Te huarahi ki te ora; The Legacy of Henry Williams and William Williams''. Published by Evagean Publishing, 266 Shaw Road, Titirangi, Auckland NZ. {{ISBN|0-908951-16-7}} (soft cover), {{ISBN|0-908951-17-5}} (hard cover), {{ISBN|0-908951-18-3}} (leather bound) *Fitzgerald, Caroline (2004) ''Letters from the Bay of Islands'', Sutton Publishing Limited, United Kingdom; {{ISBN|0-7509-3696-7}} (Hardcover). Penguin Books, New Zealand, (Paperback) {{ISBN|0-14-301929-5}} * Fitzgerald, Caroline (2011) ''Te Wiremu - Henry Williams: Early Years in the North'', Huia Publishers, New Zealand {{ISBN|978-1-86969-439-5}} * Gillies, Iain and John (1998) ''East Coast Pioneers. A Williams Family Portrait; A Legacy of Land, Love and Partnership''. Published by The Gisborne Herald Co. Ltd, Gladstone Road, Gisborne NZ. {{ISBN|0-473-05118-4}} * Mitcalfe, Barry (1963) ''Nine New Zealanders''. Christchurch : Whitcombe and Tombs. The chapter 'Angry peacemaker: Henry Williams – A missionary's courage wins Maori converts' (p. 32 - 36) * Rogers, Lawrence M., (1973) ''Te Wiremu: A Biography of Henry Williams'', Pegasus Press * Williams, William (1867) – ''Christianity among the New Zealanders''. London. [https://archive.org/details/christianityamon00willrich Online available ] from Archive.org. * Williams, W. ''The Turanga journals'', 1840–1850. Ed. F. Porter. Wellington, 1974 [http://www.enzb.auckland.ac.nz/document?wid=3676&action=null Online available ] from ENZB * Woods, S. M. ''Marianne Williams'', Christchurch, 1977

{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=September 2010}} {{orphan|date=April 2010}} {{cleanup|date=April 2011}} }}
'''The Milton Fisher Scholarship for Innovation and Creativity''' is an annual four-year [[scholarship]] sponsored by the [[Renée B. Fisher Foundation]] and housed at the [[Community Foundation for Greater New Haven]]. Four-year scholarships of varying amounts based on need are awarded to high school juniors and seniors, and college freshmen, who will be attending a university in the [[Connecticut]] and the [[New York City]] metropolitan area.
==Purpose== Since 2003, the Milton Fisher Scholarship has sought to reward students who have demonstrated exceptional originality in [[problem solving]]. In particular, applicants are those students who have: *solved an artistic, scientific, or technical problem in new or unusual ways *created a distinctive solution to a problem faced by a school, community, or family *developed an original and innovative approach to save the environment or improve people’s health
Recipients are selected on the basis of their applications, which include [[essay]]s and [[Letter of recommendation|letters of recommendation]]. The deadline for applications varies each year but is often in early to mid-April.
==Name== The scholarship is named for [[Milton Fisher]], an [[lawyer|attorney]] and [[investment banker]] from New York City who made his home in Connecticut from 1960 until his death in 2001. He served on the boards of several public companies, and was the author several books, including two about [[Wall Street]]. His book ''Intuition: How to Use it in Your Life'' has been translated into several languages.
Additionally, he was also deeply devoted to the development of original thinking and [[creative process]]es. For over 25 years, he taught a unique course for adults called "Applied Creativity", which focused less on [[creativity]] as expressed in the arts (as it is often understood), and more on helping people be more creative in all aspects of their lives, developing creative problem-solving skills and innovative approaches to challenges they faced individually, or that faced their community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rbffoundation.org/about_mfs.html|title=Milton Fisher Scholarship for Innovation and Creativity|website=www.rbffoundation.org}}</ref>
==References== <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.rbffoundation.org Milton Fisher Scholarship official website]
